column1: Ciudad Obregón is the second largest city in the northern Mexican state of Sonora and named for Sonoran revolutionary general and president of Mexico
column2: Álvaro Obregón. It is 525 km (326 mi) south of the state's northern border with the US state of Arizona. It is also the municipal seat of Cajeme municipality
column3: located in the Yaqui Valley.

column1: == History ==
The city
column2: previously named Cajeme
column3: takes its name from Mexican Revolutionary Álvaro Obregón
column4: a native of nearby Huatabampo
column5: Sonora. Álvaro Obregón became president of Mexico after the Revolution and initiated an "agricultural revolution" in the Yaqui Valley
column6: introducing modern agricultural techniques and making this valley one of the most prosperous agricultural regions in the country. Renowned US agronomist Dr. Norman Borlaug
column7: the architect of the "Green Revolution" worked here after successful developments in increasing the resistance of wheat. For his efforts he was later awarded the Nobel Prize.

column1: The origins of this city date back to the year 1906 when the company's rail track South Pacific Railway reached this area of the Yaqui Valley; this route
column2: made it possible to incorporate with the Mayo Valley to the domestic and external market
column3: attracting a wave of investors and settlers who brought out populations.

column2: a flag station was established for the locomotive crossing the state to supply water
column3: this station was called Cajeme. Cajemé was a Yaqui leader (whose population lives in this area) who fought against them as part of the Porphyrian army; and then led the Yaqui rebellion against it Porfirio Díaz.

column1: The Cajeme station was run by the American Bert Cameron, superintendent, and Emilio Estrella, station manager. They and their families were the first settlers. Soon after, the cowboys arrived to guard the corrals of cattle that from here was sent to other regions. Soon came neighbors of Hope, near the fields cultivated in the Valley. The Yaquis offered resistance to the arrival of the first settlers on their lands.
The first neighborhood was called Plan Oriente. In 1923
column2: 'Cajeme Motors' was installed
column3: owned by American James Huffaker
column4: it was the first auto agency; fact that contributed significantly to the development of Cajeme. At the end of his term as president of the country (1920–1924)
column5: the General Alvaro Obregón returned to Sonora and carried out business projects in Navojoa and Cajeme
column8: which provided more work and economic development in the Region.

column1: 29 November 1927 was declared the head of the municipality (until then it had been part of Cocorit) by the governor Fausto Topete
column2: and in 1928 year in which the first town hall was installed
column3: it was decreed on 28 July of the same year on 28 July of the same year change of name to Ciudad Obregón in recognition of Alvaro Obregón
column4: while the name of the municipality was preserved. That same year the first printing press was installed and it was where the first news weekly called 'The Pacific Gazette'
column5: owned by Lithuanian immigrant Leo Rosenfeld and his wife Virginia Gámez

column1: The first colonies were Plano Oriente
column2: Ladrillera
column3: Cumuripa
column4: Hidalgo
column5: Constitución
column8: Bella Vista and Colonia del Valle.

column1: Rice was the most important crop in the Yaqui Valley in the early [twentieth century]; other crops also include wheat
column2: beans
column3: chickpeas
column4: various vegetables and alfalfa. Over the course of the century
column5: wheat became the most important crop. Due to Cajeme's agricultural vocation
column6: the first industry of great importance was rice mills.

column1: In the 1950s the agronomist Norman E. Borlaug (called the Father of the Green Revolution) collaborated with the creation of the Northwest Agricultural Research Center (CIANO) and in 1970 received the Nobel Peace Prize for his work in research developing better varieties of wheat and maize.
At the end of the twentieth century the railway disappeared as a means of transport for passengers and the station was abandoned.
For the development of productive activities
column2: local commerce offers everything from re-shareholders
column3: agricultural implement stores
column4: agribusiness machinery
column5: safety equipment and all kinds of inputs for production. There are two markets for supplies.

column1: For the realization of economic activities and service to the general public
column2: Ciudad Obregón has offices of the main financial institutions of the country.

column1: == Geography ==
The city is located on the parallel 27–29' north latitude and the meridian 109-59' west longitude. With an altitude above sea level of 40.8 m in the city center.
It is located in the south of the State of Sonora
column2: 50 kilometers from the coast of the Sea of Cortez and 100 kilometers from the Sierra Madre Occidental
column3: is also 240 km from Hermosillo
column4: the capital of the State; and 530 kilometers from the border with The United States.

column1: == Climate ==
Ciudad Obregón has a steppe climate (Köppen BWh) featuring long
column2: extremely hot summers and short
column3: mild winters with cold mornings. It is frequent that in summer the temperature reach 40 °C (104.0 °F) or more
column4: with overnight lows greater than 24 °C (75 °F) and sometimes reaching 30 °C (86 °F). Sunny skies and clear nights can be expected through all the year. Many severe thunderstorms with strong winds and sandstorms reach the region in summer. Rainfall is scarce but it is more prominent in the summer. In the winter
column5: daytime temperatures can be hotter than 26 °C (79 °F) but at night the temperature can fall to 2 °C (36 °F). Snow in Ciudad Obregón is nonexistent
column6: but hailstorms can occur during cold fronts.

column1: The extreme temperatures recorded in the box below between 1939 and 2016 were recorded at the Downtown Station of Ciudad Obregón
column2: Sonora.

column1: == City origins ==
Cajeme Municipality has as its head Ciudad Obregón. Its first settlers established themselves in the neighborhood called Plano Oriente
column2: as irrigation canals made by the Richardson company around 1910 and two years later
column3: the South Pacific railroad established a station called Cajeme. The town of Cajeme was initially a part of Cocorit Municipality until its elevation to Municipal Seat on 28 September 1927. The first city government was established on 1 January 1928. The 28 July 1928 decree stated that "the city is known now with the name of Ciudad Obregón
column4: the town formerly known as Cajeme." In 1937 another legislation stated that Cajeme be the name of the Municipality and Ciudad Obregón its seat.

== Roots and traditions ==
The Yaqui people are settled in eight towns
column2: Potam
column3: Huirivis
column4: Torim
column5: Cocorit
column8: Rahum and Belem. seven kilometres (4.3 miles) from the city is the first of the eight Yaqui towns that make the autonomous territory of these people known for their independent character
column9: because it is one of the few American ethnic groups not dominated militarily by Spanish colonialists.

column1: Yaqui history is covered with acts of heroic resistance for the defense of their territory and culture
column2: an ancestral culture enriched by rites and traditions of which the Deer Dance stands out
column3: a symbolic representation of the hunt for this animal whose aesthetic richness has awakened interest the world over.

column1: In the rites of Passover and Easter
column2: or in the Day of the Dead celebration
column3: Yaqui culture reaches its highest splendor and shows us the survival of mystery
column4: the unity of man with the universe and the intimate relationship between people and the nature that surrounds them.

column1: One day the wind of Passover takes the Pharisees to roam the nearby cities hidden behind leather masks; another day rivalries and mundane ambitions are forgotten so that the whole tribe may join in the commemoration of its faithfully departed. Men and women that practice traditional medicine apply ancient knowledge passed on by their ancestors and with herbs and ointments cure the sickness of their relatives.
Dance
column2: music
column3: traditional medicine and Yaqui festivities are the expression of a magical world of religion that coexists in harmony with western culture. Obregon City is also Birthplace to one of its most notorious past inhabitants: El huilito Rojas from the very first settlement in obregon city: plano oriente of Cardenas Ave. and Guerrero.

column1: == Demographics ==
Ciudad Obregón is the second largest city in Sonora (after state capital Hermosillo) with a 2010 census population of 298 625 People. Its municipality of Cajeme had a population of 409
column2: 310.As of 2005 the per capita income for the municipality of Cajeme was $10
column3: 940 and the Human Development Index was 0.8635.

column1: == Government and economy ==
In Ciudad Obregón lies the seat of the municipal government of Cajeme. The government's exercise rests with the Municipal President and his cabinet
column2: elected every three years.

column1: The main economic activities in the entity are maquiladora

column4: [aquaculture]

column8: because of its relatively recent foundation

The city is served by Ciudad Obregón International Airport.

== Tourism ==
=== Nainari Lagoon ===
A peculiar tourist attraction
column2: a product of man's whimsy is the artificial "Nainari Lagoon" with a 2 kilometres (1.2 miles) perimeter located at the western city limits between Guerrero and Padre Eusebio Kino avenues. It is used for outdoor sports
column3: and its two piers are a focal point for aquatic activities like skiing
column4: sailing and canoeing being the site for triathlons
column5: marathons
column6: and bicycle races. Cold coconut stands where you can find the freshest coconuts and other fruits such as mango con chile
column7: and restaurants.This small oasis is artificial
column9: one of the great achievements of City Mayor Rene Gandara
column10: who opened the hydraulic gates to fill the reservoir. Before
column11: it was a lagoon region where there was duck hunting and rice was grown.

column1: The Nainari Lagoon is a tourist attraction that has small boardwalk and a boat dock. It also has a shelter for tourists by the water's edge.
Water is constantly circulating as it is connected with one of the main canals in the irrigation district
column2: the Lower Canal.

column1: The Lagoon has been in recent years better tended and remodeled by the authorities. It has at its entrance a small garden with a bronze statue of a discus thrower which gives it much enhancement.
Just next to the lagoon there is a sports complex "deportivo". It has an Olympic size swimming pool and it has all types of sport courts such as tennis
column2: basketball
column3: soccer
column4: and fronton.

column1: === Ostimuri Children's Park ===
Next to the Nainari Lagoon we have the Ostimuru Children's Park and the Ostimuri Zoo
column2: the best place to stroll with the family
column3: here you will find an ample variety of mechanical rides for your children. The trees that surround this place cover it with lush branches like a caress from the sky.

column1: At the park's edge is the Ostimuri Zoo – an artificial habitat where a wide variety of animals exist
column2: the song of birds as you stroll through this place is like a melody from heaven. As you make your journey in the midst of animals
column3: you are surpassed by a boa as if it were a guardian of this place.

column1: === Yaqui Museum ===
The museum offers a perspective of Yaqui culture having among its objectives rescuing
column2: preserving
column3: investigating and spreading the culture and way of life of the Yaquis. As well as stimulating in the state's population the rediscovery of historical
column4: linguistic and ethnic values of the Yaquis. Another objective is to show Sonoran children and teens the particular characteristics of Yaqui personality and the richness of their folklore. Another objective is to raise consciousness among Sonorans in regards to the development of historical events of the Yaquis as well as the important influence that they had in the formation of groups and classes that constitute the regions current society. This is made more accessible through visuals and scenes of daily life of the population of said tribe
column5: mounted with the instruments
column6: tools and original clothing that has been with them since ancient times and distinguish them on and international level.

column1: === Cocorit House ===
This construction dates from the previous century
column2: its architecture is of colonial style. It has four exhibition rooms and an ample garden where we find permanent samples of painting and sculptures as well as arts and crafts. Among the House's visitors is the internationally renowned sculpture and painter Jose Luis Cuevas.

column1: Among the objectives of Cocorit House is to support art in those people with artistic attributes that don't have enough support. That is why local artists call it the region's haven for the arts.
=== "Álvaro Obregón" Dam ===
The General Álvaro Obregón Dam also called the Oviachic Dam
column2: named taken from the place where it is located
column3: starts its construction in the year 1947 and it's finished in 1952
column4: being filled for the first time on July the same year. It is located 35 kilometres (22 miles) north of Ciudad Obregón.

column1: Lake Oviachic has a surface of 20
column2: 500 acres (83 square kilometres) and a storage capacity of 3226 millions of cubic meters; it is part of the dam system on the Yaqui River
column3: it's the state's largest dam and the third located on said river.

column1: From the Oviachic Dam a 27
column2: 603-kilometre (17
column3: 152-mile) network of main and secondary canals is derived that irrigate 450
column4: 000 hectares (1
column6: 000 acres) of surface in the Yaqui and Mayo Valleys
column7: being one of the most important hydraulic infrastructures in the country.

column1: During the last two decades this hydraulic work has become one of the main and most visited tourist destinations in our region.
=== Huivulai Island ===
Huivulai Island is located 50 kilometres (31 miles) south of Ciudad Obregón and 5 miles (8.0 kilometres) off the Sonora coast in the Gulf of California (Sea of Cortez). In Mayo
column2: Huivulai means "long neck". The island is 17 kilometres (10.6 miles) long and 1.2 kilometres (0.7 miles) wide at its widest part. The island features many natural attractions including sand dunes used by four-wheel drive vehicles. The island has a water well oasis surrounded by date trees that attract many species of birds
column3: including gray and white pelicans
column4: corvetta
column5: gray crested cranes
column7: and albatrosses. The island is ringed by beaches and features fishing opportunities off-shore.

column1: == Festivals and cultural programs ==
=== Tetabiakte Art and Culture Festival ===

This festival of art and culture takes place in November to celebrate the anniversary of the founding of the municipality of Cajeme with the support of the Institute of Municipal Culture and the National Council for Culture and the Arts ([CONACULTA]). This festival offers music
column2: painting
column3: film
column4: poetry
column5: book presentations and shows the culture and traditions of the Yaqui ethnic group.

column1: === ITSON Arts Festival ===
The Festival
column2: promoted by the Instituto Tecnológico de Sonora through the Directorate of Extension of Culture and Services and is held annually in October. The Festival is a member of the National Network of Festivals of the National Council for Culture and the Arts (CONACULTA). The program serves audiences of higher middle education
column3: university and the community at large
column4: through an artistic program representative of our cultural diversity
column5: with national quality groups
column8: with close access to the commun

column1: === Ars Vocalis México ===
Ars Vocalis México is an international festival and academy dedicated to vocal art that in 2015 is hosted by Ciudad Obregón. This festival
column2: founded by the tenor and cultural promoter Carlos Zapién
column3: has a pedagogical program thanks to which young Mexican singers
column4: previously selected through an audition process
column5: have the opportunity to participate in classes lectures given by renowned figures in the operatic world of Europe and the United States
column6: as well as being able to work with coaches from various opera houses and educational institutions. Students also have the opportunity to work on the German vocal repertoire (Lied)
column7: ancient and baroque music and Mexican music. The audience has the opportunity to listen to recitals and operatic performances at no cost.

column1: === IPN International Book Fair ===
Since 2013
column2: the National Polytechnic Institute has organized the International Book Fair held in September. The program has been attended by renowned figures in the literary field
column3: such as Elena Poniatowska and the program has the cooperation of several governmental and private institutions.

column1: == Sports ==

column2: who play at Tomás Oroz Gaytán Stadium.
